Award.AwardTitle: NSF/DOE Partnership on Advanced Combustion Engines: Ignition and Combustion Characteristics of Transportation Fuels under Lean-Burn Conditions for Advanced Engine Concepts

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
#1258720
Lee, Seong-Young

Use of dimethyl ether (DME) in the internal combustion engine (ICE) has significant advantages over gasoline and diesel fuels, potentially yielding very low NOx emissions and zero particulate matter (PM). One usage is through low-temperature combustion (LTC) strategies, the focus of which aims to (i) develop a predictive capability for DME combustion and (ii) develop a high-pressure (>1500 bar) DME fuel injection system. Fundamental, phenomenological, and quantitative studies will be carried out over a wide range of pressures and temperatures, utilizing state-of-the-art experimental facilities along with strong synergistic theoretical and computational efforts. The outcome will be a comprehensive characterization of DME high-pressure spray combustion, a determination of highly dilute DME autoignition (i.e., engine knock) phenomenon as a function of thermo-chemical and chemical kinetic parameters, development of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) predictive tools for emissions and combustion efficiency, and optimization of a high pressure DME fuel system. In this joint effort among Michigan Technological University, Argonne National Laboratory, Alternative Fuel Technology, and Navistar, the experimental facilities and expertise of individual partners will be leveraged. Not only will this collaboration contribute to the development of an advanced ICE fueled with DME, significant educational impacts will also result. An integrated educational program provides research opportunities for students through close collaboration with Argonne National Laboratory and the industrial partners.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Use of dimethyl ether (DME), a natural-gas derived liquid fuel, in the internal combustion engine has significant advantages with traditional fuels (gasoline and diesel) on an energy equivalent basis, yielding low emissions and zero particulate matter, and improved efficiency. Shortcomings include highly energy intensive processes for gas-to-liquid conversion and much lower energy density on a volume basis. Use of DME in advanced engine concepts with high efficiency pursues lean-burn combustion, high injection pressures, and high exhaust gas recirculation (EGR). This proposal aimed for a fundamental, phenomenological, and quantitative study on the energy conversion method over a wide range of pressures and temperatures, utilizing state-of-the-art experimentation along with strong synergistic theoretical and computational efforts.

Intellectual Merits:  

DME combustion yields very low NOx but higher CO and HC emissions due to much higher DME volatility and reactivity. Limited engine testing has shown that with the use of high injection pressures, DME offers the potential to meet 2010 HD diesel emission standards without any aftertreatment system while maintaining very high engine efficiencies. For future engine strategies to extend the DME application use of (i) higher injection pressures (above 1500 bar), much capable pressures compared to the present day 300 bar operation, and (ii) low temperature combustion strategies, such as lean-burn and high EGR concepts are envisioned.

In the first fiscal year (9/2013 – 8/2014), the goal was mainly focused on experimental preparation and hardware fabrication: (i) Designed and fabricated the DME injector window mounted in the combustion vessel facility; (ii) Fabricated the fuel delivery system of hydraulically activated electronic unit injector along with interface controller; (iii) Measured the rate of injection for DME and diesel fuels with various injection pressures; (iv) Conducted experiment of non-vaporizing, vaporizing, and combusting spray and auto-ignition test using rapid compression machine (RCM); (v) Developed various DME detailed and reduced chemistries for the predictive tool modeling.

In the second year (9/2014 – 8/2015), project entered the testing phase. More advanced hardware and various diagnostic techniques were applied in the experiments. The major accomplished were as following: (i) Designed and procured three different sized single-hole injector nozzles along with the second generation fuel injection system with more advanced capability of higher injection rate, multiple injection strategy, and general optimization of injection control; (ii) Characterized the rate of injection measurement of fuels up to 2000 bar injection pressure, later used for CFD modeling; (iii) Conducted experiments and analyzed data for non-vaporizing, vaporizing, and combusting spray. The temporal and spatial formation of intermediate species was measured using laser-based measurement; (iv) Performed kinetics and simplified spray modeling and 3-D RANS CFD simulations; (v) Conducted RCM experiment to characterize diluted DME ignition processes.

The third year goal (9/2015 – 8/2016) continued focusing on high injection pressure testing of DME: (i) Spray with multi-hole nozzle was characterized by rate of injection measurement and experiment; (ii) Ambient conditions (temperature, density, oxygen concentration), injection duration and injection pressure were varied when performing non-reacting and reacting spray of DME and diesel for comparison; (iii) Developed CFD simulation together with experimental results provided a detailed picture of the DME combustion process under tested conditions; (iv) Preliminary data from engine testing of diesel and DME were obtained using current baseline engine hardware. Both engine and CV data showed higher reactivity of DME resulted in earlier ignition than diesel did. Some optimizations were identified for fuel injection system based on initial engine experiment to further accommodate for the higher compressibility and lower fuel energy content of the DME; (v) Developed an one-dimensional injector model in MATLAB/SIMULINK graphical software environment.

The fourth year goal (9/2016 – 8/2017) was to further explore the spray and combustion characteristic of high injection pressure DME and its comparison with diesel. Major activities were listed: (i) Investigated understand the flame structure, ignition and lift-off behaviors of DME spray flame, we developed detailed CFD of DME sprays with validated experimental combustion data; (ii) Validated CFD simulations against engine experiments; (iii)  Updated injector modeling for multi-hole DME and diesel injectors; (iv) Demonstrated and preliminarily explored low-temperature combustion of DME spray; (v) Revisited previous experimental data, and improved post-processing method;

Broader Impacts:

The outcome of the proposal potentially transforms the development of low emission alternative fuel of the internal combustion engine in the U.S. The project has supported three PhD graduate students (one full support and two partial supports) to conduct and analyze the results and assist the project organization, three MS students to assist in the test and two undergraduate students to support the design of injector window. Throughout this project, we hosted and demonstrated the scientific knowledge related to this unique combustion vessel through Michigan Tech Summer Youth Program (SYP). Middle school and high school students visited and got lectures by our graduate students to show the basic concept of compressed flame ignition and shadowgraph.
